ATHENS, GA 30602

citations.narrative:
Per facility records, during routine husbandry cleaning of the rhesus macaques’ primary indoor enclosures on March 17,
2024, a singly housed female rhesus macaque was able to gain access to another singly housed female rhesus
macaque, within their shared bank of cages, by sliding the floor of her enclosure open. This macaque was able to slide
the floor open due to the latches on the floor grate not being secured by a staff member during cleaning, per a facility
representative. The two macaques got into a short scuffle, were quickly separated, and then assessed with no injuries or
bleeding observed. A more thorough exam was conducted the following day during a pre-planned sedation for routine
care. At that time, 117-18 was found to have a 2-centimeter-long laceration at her perineum requiring cleaning, suturing,
and antibiotics.
Not securing the two floor latches between the primary indoor enclosures during cleaning procedures allowed these two
macaques to interact, get into a fight resulting in an injury, and distress. Animals must be handled in a manner that does
not cause trauma, behavioral stress, physical harm, or unnecessary discomfort.
Corrected prior to inspection.

On April 27, 2023, it was determined by the facility that the automated lighting system program for seven indoor rooms
housing Old World macaques had been inadvertently altered from 12 hours light:12 hours dark to 24 hours of light with no
dark cycle. An internal investigation found this had been occurring since September 28, 2022, after some changes to light
cycles were initiated to facilitate some repairs and painting in other rooms.
Not having the lights turn off did not provide for a diurnal light cycle and did not allow the animals housed indoors to be
able to get away from constant lighting. The lights needed to be turned off for a period of time that allowed for a natural
light cycle for the animals to provide for their health and wellbeing. The facility must ensure that primates housed in indoor
enclosures be provided a diurnal light cycle ensuring normal day/night cycles.
Corrected prior to inspection.

One female rhesus macaque (116-18) on June 13, 2023, was able to place her left hand through a vertical gap in her
primary indoor enclosure and into another macaque’s enclosure, resulting in bite injuries to two digits requiring
amputation, per facility records. These enclosures were acquired from a commercial manufacturer designed for rhesus
macaques. Each enclosure had a wider vertical gap at the side of each door, which allowed the contact.
Allowing unwanted contact between the animals in separate primary enclosures caused stress and an injury requiring
surgical repair. Primary enclosures must be constructed and maintained so that they keep other unwanted animals from
entering the enclosure or having physical contact with the nonhuman primates.
Corrected prior to inspection.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
STEPHANIE MAYARD, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.38(f)(1)  Critical Repeat
   
Miscellaneous. 
Per facility records, during routine husbandry cleaning of the rhesus macaques’ primary indoor enclosures on March 17, 
2024, a singly housed female rhesus macaque was able to gain access to another singly housed female rhesus 
macaque, within their shared bank of cages, by sliding the floor of her enclosure open. This macaque was able to slide 
the floor open due to the latches on the floor grate not being secured by a staff member during cleaning, per a facility 
representative. The two macaques got into a short scuffle, were quickly separated, and then assessed with no injuries or 
bleeding observed. A more thorough exam was conducted the following day during a pre-planned sedation for routine 
care. At that time, 117-18 was found to have a 2-centimeter-long laceration at her perineum requiring cleaning, suturing, 
and antibiotics.  
 
Not securing the two floor latches between the primary indoor enclosures during cleaning procedures allowed these two 
macaques to interact, get into a fight resulting in an injury, and distress. Animals must be handled in a manner that does 
not cause trauma, behavioral stress, physical harm, or unnecessary discomfort.  
 
Corrected prior to inspection. 
3.76(c) 
   
Indoor housing facilities. 
On April 27, 2023, it was determined by the facility that the automated lighting system program for seven indoor rooms 
housing Old World macaques had been inadvertently altered from 12 hours light:12 hours dark to 24 hours of light with no 
dark cycle. An internal investigation found this had been occurring since September 28, 2022, after some changes to light 
cycles were initiated to facilitate some repairs and painting in other rooms.  
 
Not having the lights turn off did not provide for a diurnal light cycle and did not allow the animals housed indoors to be 
able to get away from constant lighting. The lights needed to be turned off for a period of time that allowed for a natural 
light cycle for the animals to provide for their health and wellbeing. The facility must ensure that primates housed in indoor 
enclosures be provided a diurnal light cycle ensuring normal day/night cycles.  
 
Corrected prior to inspection.

3.80(a)(2)(iv)  Critical
   
Primary enclosures. 
One female rhesus macaque (116-18) on June 13, 2023, was able to place her left hand through a vertical gap in her 
primary indoor enclosure and into another macaque’s enclosure, resulting in bite injuries to two digits requiring 
amputation, per facility records. These enclosures were acquired from a commercial manufacturer designed for rhesus 
macaques. Each enclosure had a wider vertical gap at the side of each door, which allowed the contact.  
 
Allowing unwanted contact between the animals in separate primary enclosures caused stress and an injury requiring 
surgical repair. Primary enclosures must be constructed and maintained so that they keep other unwanted animals from 
entering the enclosure or having physical contact with the nonhuman primates.  
 
Corrected prior to inspection. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
STEPHANIE MAYARD, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

species.common: DOMESTIC PIG / POTBELLY PIG / MICRO PIG
